utterances: And to all the voters, I want to thank you for putting me through my paces.
I will be a better mayor because of that.
I will carry your voices, your concerns into the office of the mayor's office.
Emanuel won the runoff with 56 percent of the vote compared to 44 percent for Cook County Commissioner Jesus Chuy Garcia.
(SOUNDBITE OF POLITICAL RALLY)
We didn't lose today.
We tried today.
(APPLAUSE)
In his concession speech, Garcia, who had hoped to make history as the city's first Latino mayor, urged others who would come after him to try as well.
(SOUNDBITE OF POLITICAL RALLY)
And someday, one of you will be standing right here where I am tonight.
(APPLAUSE)
Emanuel raised more than $23 million for his re-election bid and plastered the airwaves with ads.
In sum, he attacked Garcia as too inexperienced to handle the city's fiscal problems.
In others, he acknowledged that he had an abrasive personality that may have rubbed some the wrong way.
Garcia raised about $6 million with the help in part of two major unions, including the Chicago Teachers Union, which has long been at odds with Emanuel.
The union's Jesse Sharkey says Garcia was able to build an impressive coalition of Latinos, whites, blacks and labor.
And we put the political establishment in this city on the run and on the defensive over the last several months.
I think it's going to change the political conversation in the city.
And maybe in the nation since the race became symbolic of the battle between moderate and progressive factions of the Democratic Party.
But Emanuel says he's been listening and ready for change.
(SOUNDBITE OF POLITICAL RALLY)
I'm proud of what we've accomplished in these past four years.
But I understand the challenges we face will require me to approach them differently and work in a different fashion.
Those challenges include serious fiscal problems, deeply underfunded pensions and a budget deficit expected to grow to more than a billion dollars by next year.
Cheryl Corley, NPR News, Chicago.
A few years ago a musician named Justin Vernon went to live in a cabin in rural Wisconsin.
His band had broken up and so too had his relationship.
A few months later, Justin Vernon emerged with new songs that would make up one of the most critically acclaimed albums of 2008.
His new band was called Bon Iver.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""LUMP SUM"")
(Singing) Sold my cold knot - a heavy stone.
Now Justin Vernon is a producer with his own label and a big champion of other artists from the Wisconsin town where he started out.
Eau Claire, Wis., is a college town right on the western edge of Wisconsin.
It has produced a remarkable amount of notable indie musicians.
That's music reporter Andrea Swensson.
She is with a radio station at Minnesota Public Radio called The Current.
And she's going to tell us about a singer who once rivaled Vernon as one of Eau Claire's musicians to watch.
These two songwriters were kind of going head-to-head.
Both were in two of the most well-respected bands in the scene.
But while Justin Vernon went on to become a star with the band Bon Iver, the other guy, whose name is Josh Scott, kind of fell off the map.
He stopped making music for a few years.
Now working with Justin Vernon, Josh Scott has put together a band and produced a record.
The band's called Aero Flynn.
And their song ""Dk/Pi"" is Andrea Swensson's pick for this month's Heavy Rotation.
It's the music project where we ask public radio folks to name a new favorite song.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""DK/PI"")
(Singing) What are you if you (unintelligible).
What are you doing tonight?
I really like the cosmic nature of the song.
You know, it starts with this little twinkle.
And then it grows into this very spacey rock sound - really reminiscent of Radiohead and all of those great kind of moody rock bands.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""DK/PI"")
(Singing) Bring your body up with (unintelligible) for you.
Well, most of conservative legal Washington I expect to be there and also liberals who were Scalia's friends.
That includes Vice President Biden.
Antonin Scalia was one of these guys who really didn't care what your politics were.
If you liked him, he liked you.
He was not doctrinal in his friendships.
And so I expect that it'll be somewhat mixed.
Sen.
Cruz is said to be coming.
I talked to one of Scalia's closest friends yesterday who said that Scalia certainly know who Cruz was.
He's running for president.
But, Cruz said he was going because he had this connection to the Supreme Court from when he was a clerk for Chief Justice Rehnquist.
And my source said, well, unfortunately, Scalia really didn't remember him from his clerkship at all.
NPR legal affairs correspondent Nina Totenberg, Nina, thank you.
Thank you, Linda.
Good morning.
I'm David Greene.
Yesterday we reported on people throwing sliced cheese at their babies and filming it.
Well, today's throwing things update is throwing Vans sneakers across the room and filming it.
The purpose is to prove or disprove the theory that Vans always land faceup.
People have posted videos with reactions like, this is crazy, perfect landing.
Guy named Chris tweeted, I had to explain to my mom why I was throwing all my Vans on the floor at 12 a.m. Yeah, Chris, why?
It's Thursday, the day we read from your letters.
Here with me now to sort through all the mail is producer and editor Christopher Johnson.
Hey, Christopher.
Hey, Farai.
How you doing?
Doing great.
What are folks writing about?
Well, on Christmas Day, last week, Farai, you spoke with gospel singer Kirk Franklin.
He opened up about some rough times he's been going through with his family.
But who also has some light moments like this one with Franklin joking about how to discipline kids when they act like they have lost their minds.
I don't have a problem popping my little ones on their behind when they try to get too, you know, crazy.
And because there are a lot of kids I see in grocery stores and I was, like, ma'am, please, can I pop your child?
Please, here's my number, and if you need somebody to whip your kids, you can page me 24 hours.
I'm saying, I thought about starting a little side job and give me some cards and say, IWillWhipYourKids.com.
Kirk may have thought that was funny, but listener Madeleine Marv(ph) of Ithaca, New York was no not amused.

Madeleine writes, for Kirk Franklin, who was abandoned by his parents and raised by relatives, who - according to him - raised him in this manner to be propagating the same kind of misunderstanding and anger, only shows me that he is still under the thumb of that abuse and very much in denial.
But you, as a journalist, your inability to be a critical voice in that conversation was beyond disappointing.
Did I hear you actually giggle?
We also got a letter about our tribute to Canadian jazz pianist, Oscar Peterson.
Peterson died last week at the age of 82.
And Barry Solan(ph) in Newark, Delaware, felt we didn't give Mr. Peterson his due.
Barry writes, when speaking of the latter years of Oscar's life and career, you wrote it off by saying merely, after his stroke in 1993, Oscar slowed down.
The piece reduces this period of Oscar's life to be in some sort of post-career epilogue.
It ignored both the great recordings that were produced during this period and the inspiring approach that Oscar took in his response to this unexpected melody.
Oscar chose to struggle and rethink his approach to the piano as opposed to resting on his laurels as the NEWS & NOTES piece implies.
But it's not all bad news from the mailbag.
Elias Segarra(ph) in Santa Rosa, California, sent us a little love.
I want to thank you for a great program, he writes.
The fairness of the way you treat your subjects makes your program the best in my list.
I'm not African-American, but I feel I don't have to be in order to listen to your program.
The way you shine a light on subjects no other program deals with makes me feel welcome - actually, at home.
The very best for Ms. Chideya and all the folks that work on this program.
Hey, Elias, thank you so much.
We really appreciate the big up here.
Make sure you stay tuned.
We have some great radio coming up in the new year, particularly, on the political tip.
(Soundbite of music)
But for now, that's it for letters.
Please keep yours coming.
To write us, just log on to npr.org and click on Contact Us.
Please be sure to tell us where you're writing from and how to pronounce your name.
